title: Overly specific PartialEq impl for Option and Result

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: C-feature-request
labels.description: Category: A feature request, i.e: not implemented / a PR.

body:
#### I tried this code:

```rust
// This works:
let s1: String = "foo".to_owned();
let s2: &str = "foo";
s1 == s2;

// But these don't:
let o1: Option<String> = Some("foo".to_owned());
let o2: Option<&str> = Some("foo");
o1 == o2;

let r1: Result<String, ()> = Ok("foo".to_owned());
let r2: Result<&str, ()> = Ok("foo");
r1 == r2;
```

([playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=1eb53b21200dd1036a1febd42d5cd8f7))

This is because `PartialEq` impls are `#[derive]`d for `Option` and `Result`, which gives them conservative bounds.

Instead of current

```rust
impl<T> PartialEq<Option<T>> for Option<T>
where
    T: PartialEq<T>
```

I'd expect

```rust
impl<A, B> PartialEq<Option<B>> for Option<A>
where
    A: PartialEq<B>
```

and likewise, for `Result`

```rust
impl<T1, T2, E1, E2> PartialEq<Result<T2, E2>> for Result<T1, E1>
where
    T1: PartialEq<T2>,
    E1: PartialEq<E2>,
```

Note that this is similar to what `Vec<T>` already implements:

```rust
impl<A, B> PartialEq<Vec<B>> for Vec<A>
where
    A: PartialEq<B>
```

### Meta

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.45.2 (d3fb005a3 2020-07-31)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: d3fb005a39e62501b8b0b356166e515ae24e2e54
commit-date: 2020-07-31
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.45.2
LLVM version: 10.0
```
